comment.author: 50889628@N08
comment._content: The sacks were rented? Didn’t realize this was done. Great photo!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/plaisanter] I didn't either, but they definitely all say "Hired Sacks"!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: The chances are that the horses and carts were hired on a daily basis also.  Each horse owner would have a cart or two and would be hired each day when a load needed to be shifted.  Not too many of the companies held a "fleet" of horses and carts as it was much less trouble and cheaper to hire in.  I remember goind down the docks in Limerick in the early 50's and seeing lines of them waiting their turrn to pick up loads from ships at the quays.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Ah, well I was just being lighthearted about the "fleet" but that is valuable information about the hiring, thanks!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: My grand aunt worked mending the hired sacks for Dennys.. The women used to sit around on the floor or on a pile of sacks and repair the sacks. They used an x pattern stitch within a square pattern of stitches. And a huge needle. Dennys had a premises in O'Connell Street in Waterford

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] Lovely background on the hired sacks, thanks!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 90012953@N07
comment._content: This pic has a deja vu look to it. It reminds me of  "Ryans the Tanners" of Pipe St Thomastown, Co. Kilkenny. I was in their yard years ago, and this looks familliar. The steeple in the background looks correct, but Thomastown Church should be to the left of it, perhaps obstructed by the gable end of a building. The yard still exists, but has had a Celtic Tiger work over, now a small enclosed apartment complex. Perhaps the sacks were filled with salt. I'll try to get access and check it out. Incidentally there is a picture of Mr Ryan and his bride of Pipe St ,Thomastown in your  Poole Collection

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/90012953@N07] That's great! Won't you come back to us if you do find out it is definitely Thomastown?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: Think its a Ryan family in New Ross Co Wexford. The steeple looks like that of St Mary's C of I church.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/90012953@N07] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] Any confirmation, either of you, on which Ryans or where??

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Streetview of St. Mary's CofI, New Ross: looks like a match. The steeple in Thomastown is similar, but not as tall, I think.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: In Thomastown's favour, I can't see a suitable yard on the OS 25" of New Ross, and this Tannery yard in Thomastown does look well placed. I think this office is in that space in Thomastown, and the architecure looks similar.

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: The key difference with those two churches (at least in recent times as shown by street view) is that the tower in Thomastown is castellated. I can't quite see in the image above, but I suspect this one is not.
